subject: Re: [junit] Re: Filtering does not appear to work in 4.3.1
msgSnippet: Michael, The suite() method is another ball of wax.  Given a class that has some JUnit 3 characteristics and some JUnit 4 characteristics, we ve been trying to
messageBody:
Michael,

The suite() method is another ball of wax. Given a class that has
some JUnit 3 characteristics and some JUnit 4 characteristics, we've
been trying to fine-tune the best guess that JUnit makes about which
runner to use. We've finally settled for simplicity:

1) If there is a @RunWith annotation, obey it.
2) If JUnit 3 can run the class, use JUnit 3
3) Use JUnit 4

You can always override this guess, by annotating with

@RunWith(TestClassRunner.class) // for JUnit 4 behavior

or

@RunWith(OldTestClassRunner.class) // for JUnit 3 behavior

Some have mentioned in tracker items that they wish steps 2 and 3 were
reversed above (only use JUnit 3 if JUnit 4 won't recognize the
class). However, for forward expansion possibilities, this way makes
more sense--JUnit 3 won't start recognizing any new test classes in
the future, but JUnit 4 might.

Thanks,

David Saff

On 7/10/07, Michael Schechter <mlschechter@...> wrote:
> David,
>
> In order to support older JUnit execution environments (Ant, Eclipse)
> which need the 3.8 hooks, our classes have suite() methods.
>
> This appears to be the deciding factor, and this is a clear change
> from JUnit 4.1. Adding the suite() method appears to route execution
> down a path that ignores the JUnit 4.x hooks (OldTestClassRunner).
>
> I have updated the bug to include this data as well.
>

> > wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Kent/David et. al.,
> > > > >
> > > > > I have been successfully using a filter implementation that I
> > provided
> > > > > with one or more method names. These methods were the only ones
> > > > > executed in the test class. Worked seamlessly with 4.1
> > > > >
> > > > > I just recently updated to JUnit 4.3.1, and the filter
> > implementation
> > > > > no longer seems to be applied. There is nothing I can find in the
> > > > > release notes that implies that this would have changed. The
> > > > > frustrating thing is that setting breakpoints in my filter has no
> > > > > effect - it is as if it is never being called.
> > > > >
> > > > > I am including the filter implementation class and the invocation
> > > > > logic. Please let me know if there is something I missed here.
> > > > >
> > > > > Thanks in advance!
> > > > >
> > > > > ------------------------------------------------
> > > > > import java.util.ArrayList;
> > > > > import java.util.List;
> > > > >
> > > > > import org.junit.runner.Description;
> > > > > import org.junit.runner.manipulation.Filter;
> > > > >
> > > > > /**
> > > > > * This class provides a mechanism to filter tests by name,
> > allowing a
> > > > > subset of the tests in a test
> > > > > * class to be defined by a developer.
> > > > > *
> > > > > * @since 2.0
> > > > > */
> > > > > public class MatchingFilter extends Filter {
> > > > >
> > > > > /**
> > > > > * The references to the tests that should be executed.
> > > > > */
> > > > > private List<Description> tests = new ArrayList<Description>();
> > > > >
> > > > > /**
> > > > > * Initializes an instance of <code>MatchingFilter</code>
> with the
> > > > > data provided.
> > > > > *
> > > > > * @param aTestClass
> > > > > * the class for which tests will be executed
> > > > > * @param someTestNames
> > > > > * the method names
> > > > > */
> > > > > public MatchingFilter(Class aTestClass, String[]
> someTestNames) {
> > > > > for (String testName : someTestNames) {
> > > > > this.tests.add(Description.createTestDescription(aTestClass,
> > > > > testName));
> > > > > }
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > /**
> > > > > * Implemented abstract method to provide detail filtering
> > > > > mechanism. Only test methods that match
> > > > > * the provided names will be executed.
> > > > > *
> > > > > * @see
> > > > >
> > > >
> >
> org.junit.runner.manipulation.Filter#shouldRun(org.junit.runner.Description)
> > > > > */
> > > > > @Override
> > > > > public boolean shouldRun(Description aDescription) {
> > > > > return this.tests.contains(aDescription);
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > /**
> > > > > * Implemented abstract method.
> > > > > *
> > > > > * @see org.junit.runner.manipulation.Filter#describe()
> > > > > */
> > > > > @Override
> > > > > public String describe() {
> > > > > return "This filter excludes any test methods that do not
> > exactly
> > > > > match the provided names";
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > ------------------------------------------------
> > > > > JUnitCore core = new JUnitCore();
> > > > > Request testRequest = Request.aClass(aTestClass);
> > > > > if (0 < someArguments.length) {
> > > > > Filter matchFilter = new MatchingFilter(aTestClass,
> > > > someArguments);
> > > > > testRequest = testRequest.filterWith(matchFilter);
> > > > > }
> > > > > core.run(testRequest);
> > > > >
> > > > > ------------------------------------------------
> > > > >
> > > > >

> > > > > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Schechter" <bard@> wrote:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Kent,
> > > > > >
> > > > > > First and foremost, thanks! That example did the trick. I was
> > able to
> > > > > > modify it, and our team can now specify any subset of the test
> > methods
> > > > > > in a given class dynamically as part of their development
> process.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I would strongly recommend that this trick (and any others that
> > > > > > require extension/implementation from JUnit core classes) be
> > added to
> > > > > > whatever "recipes" get documented.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I feel very strongly about the utility of JUnit (or any
> > similar tool)
> > > > > > in a testing-dependent development environment. The only
> > drawback I
> > > > > > can see to using volunteer labor for documentation purposes is
> > that
> > > > > > these volunteers would need access to the brains behind the
> > code to
> > > > > > write complete Javadoc. For example, in following your
> > example, I got
> > > > > > tripped up by the Request filterWith() method. So many
> frameworks
> > > > > > today return a modified instance of the class on which you are
> > > > > > operating that I was somewhat surprised that the instance on
> > which I
> > > > > > called filterWith() was not modified.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Upon reflection, your contract and implementation are perfectly
> > > > > > reasonable OO - the filtered instance is what is returned, not
> > what is
> > > > > > invoked. This is the kind of fine point that would be easy to
> > miss in
> > > > > > documenting this code as a volunteer. I point this out not as an
> > > > > > argument against. Instead, those who volunteer must be
> > cognizant of
> > > > > > the fairly subtle complexities of this framework, and be
> > willing to
> > > > > > ask questions when contributing.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Once again, thanks for the timely assist!
> > > > > >

> > raise:

> > > > > > > @Test public void runTestsInAList() {
> > > > > > > final String[] tests= new String[] {"a", "b"};
> > > > > > > Filter namedTests= new Filter() {
> > > > > > > @Override
> > > > > > > public String describe() {
> > > > > > > return "only tests starting with
> 'a'";
> > > > > > > }
> > > > > > > @Override
> > > > > > > public boolean shouldRun(Description
> > description) {
> > > > > > > for (String each : tests)
> > > > > > > if
> > > > > > > (description.getDisplayName().startsWith(each))
> > > > > > > return true;
> > > > > > > return false;
> > > > > > > }
> > > > > > > };
> > > > > > > Request request=
> > > > > > > Request.aClass(Tests.class).filterWith(namedTests);
> > > > > > > Result result= new JUnitCore().run(request);
> > > > > > > assertEquals(2, result.getRunCount());
> > > > > > > }
> > > > > > > public static class Tests {
> > > > > > > @Test public void a() {}
> > > > > > > @Test public void b() {}
> > > > > > > @Test public void c() {}
